name: Sheila Lerwill
description: Between 1947-54, high jumper Sheila Lerwill won four WAAA titles and enjoyed three other podium finishes. In beating Dorothy Odam-Tyler for the second successive year in 1951, she did so with a new world record 1.72 (5-7½), knocking 1cm off Fanny Blankers-Koen’s eight-year-old record. A member of Spartan Ladies, Lerwill’s only major international title was a gold medal at the 1950 European Championships in Bruxelles. Having won that title, and set a world record, she went to the 1952 Olympics as favourite for gold, but had to settle for Britain’s third consecutive silver in the event when finishing second to Esther Brand of South Africa. Lerwill was expected to return from the 1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games at Vancouver with a medal but could only finish a disappointing fourth with fellow Britons Thelma Hopkins and Dorothy Odam-Tyler occupying first and second place. Lerwill had another setback at that year’s European Championships at Berne when finishing fifth, with Hopkins again taking gold. Lerwill retired in 1954 to go to live in Iraq where her husband Michael was the manager of a date exporting company in Basra. They returned to England 20 months later and Sheila resumed her athletics career after giving birth to her first child, and she won the Surrey County title in 1956, six years winning her first title. Lerwill was also a Surrey county netball player. Personal Best: HJ – 1.718 (1951).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (1–0–0 1950 Bruxelles gold: high jump)

name: Ho Koh Chye
description: Ho Koh Chye kept goal for the Malaysian hockey team at the 1964 Rome Olympics and in 1968 in Mexico where he was also team captain. As a coach he led the Malaysia to their best international performance, 4th in the 1975 World Cup on home soil in Kuala Lumpur. He later worked for the National Sports Council in Malaysia and returned to the Olympics when he was chosen as team manager of the national hockey team in Barcelona. Koh Chye died of prostate cancer just a few months after acting as chef-de-mission for the Malaysian Olympic team in Beijing.
special_notes: Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Datuk) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–0–1 1962 Jakarta HOC bronze (competed for Malaya))

name: Leopoldo Palma
description: Chilean track athlete Leopoldo Palma competed in distances from 100 to 800 metres as well as the hurdles. Palma ran in the 800 metres at the 1912 Stockholm Olympics but did not finish in his heat. He was scheduled to run in the 100 metres, 400 metres, and the 4 × 100 metres relay at the Stockholm Games but did not start in those events. Palma was also the flagbearer for Chile at the Opening Ceremony in Stockholm. Four years later he won the gold medal in the 400 metres hurdles at the 1918 South American Championships in Athletics. Personal Best: 800 – unknown.

name: Joshua Cheptegei
special_notes: Listed in Current World Record Holders in Athletics (5000 m 12:35.36 (2020), 10000 m 26:11.00 (2020)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (1–1–0 2017 London silver: 10000 m; 2019 Doha gold: 10000 m) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (2–0–0 2018 Gold Coast ATH gold: 5000 m and 10000 m)

name: Demetrij Žebre
description: Slovene composer and conductor Demetrij Žebre was introduced to music by his father, a music-loving lawyer. Although he attended a music school as a pupil, Žebre enrolled at the law faculty. However, he actually studied at the Conservatory in Ljubljana and later in Praha (until 1936). In Praha, his teacher in composition was Josef Suk. Žebre then worked as a conductor at the Ljubljana Opera. After World War II he moved to Trieste and became a leading figure there as head of the local orchestra and supervisor of the music school. In 1948, he returned to Ljubljana, taking over the direction of the opera and later counselling Radio Sje. During his spell as conductor of the Croatian Opera in Zagreb (1952-58) he established himself as a leading conductor in Yugoslavia. Back in Slovenia, he became conductor and director at the Ljubljana Opera. He was married to opera singer Xenia Vidali since 1960. Žebre authored piano and chamber music, and also wrote symphonies. His style was influenced by the early avant-garde but was never extreme. He gradually abandoned contacts to radical developments in Western Europe. With time, his music was almost forgotten but experienced a revival beginning in the 1970s. Žebre’s 1936 entry is listed under the French title Cours in the catalogue of the art competitions. The original Slovenian title is Tek (The run). The 1935 composition is subtitled a “symphonic picture for full orchestra”. The approximately 11-minute long work was released on CD on a Slovenian label in 2018.

name: James Haley
description: James Haley studied at the University of North Florida, where he was on the swim team. He was also ranked in the US top 10 in fencing and combined those talents to compete in the modern pentathlon at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. Haley competed in triathlons on the side. After college Haley studied at the Northwestern Health Sciences University, earning a degree in chiropractic medicine. Haley then practiced chiropractic in Lake City, Florida. He is a member of the Florida Chiropractic Association, the American Chiropractic Association, and the World Olympians Association and has served as the Vice-President of Florida Chiropractic Association Sports Counsel.
special_notes: Husband of Henrietta Ónodi

name: Clayton Fredericks
special_notes: Husband of Lucinda Fredericks

name: Irén Rudas
description: Irén Rudas competed for the first time in 1924 as a BBTE gymnast. In 1926 Rudas won the Toldy prize with the BBTE team, which at that time was equivalent to the team championship title. In 1928 she participated in the Summer Olympic Games in Amsterdam, where as a member of the Hungarian team she finished fourth in the all-around team event (free exercise, mace exercise and low hurdle). The following year she got married and gave up competitive sports.

name: Dora Gardner
description: Dora Gardner had the following podium finishes at major championships: 2nd in the 1938 British Empire Games High Jump. In the 1938 British Empire Games long jump she finished seventh and in the 1938 European Championships high jump she finished fifth. Eight years later she finished seventh in the 1946 European Championships high jump. Personal Best: HJ – 1.625 (1948).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 1938 Sydney ATH silver: high jump (competed for England))

name: Jean Földeak
description: Jean Földeak was born with the first name János in a Romanian village in former Hungarian territory. He was a trained mechanic and in 1924 tried to immigrate to the United States, but could not get a visa. He stayed in Hamburg, where he received German citizenship in 1927. Földeak won a silver medal in Los Angeles in middleweight Greco-Roman and was fourth in welterweight freestyle. He was European champion in 1931, 1933, and 1934 in welterweight freestyle and German Champion in welterweight Greco-Roman in 1929 and freestyle in 1930. He represented Germany at seven international meetings. In 1935 Földeak became German head coach, and in 1936 coached the Polish wrestlers for the Olympics and from 1949-66 was a German federal coach. After World War II, Földeak founded a company to manufacture wrestling mats and training equipment, which is still one of the leading companies of its kind.

name: Rebecca Johnston
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (1–7–1 2008 Harbin silver; 2009 Hämeenlinna silver; 2011 Zürich and Winterthur silver; 2012 Burlington gold; 2013 Ottawa silver; 2015 Malmö silver; 2016 Kamloops silver; 2017 Plymouth silver; 2019 Espoo bronze)

name: Leon Tuck
description: Tuck went to Dartmouth, playing for three years, captaining the team as a senior, and graduating in 1915. After his college days he fought with the American Air Service in France in WWI and continued to play amateur hockey, mostly in Massachusetts. When he made the Olympic team he was a member of the Boston AA. Tuck went back to Dartmouth to coach for 3 years between 1921 and 1924, was pretty succesfull and had this record: 26 - 11 - 3. Tuck made his living as the manager of an ice cream company.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (0–1–0 1920 Antwerpen (Olympics) silver)

name: Xavi Arnau
special_notes: Brother of Jordi Arnau

name: Serghei Mariniuc

name: Elena Gigli
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Water Polo Championships (1–1–0 2006 Beograd silver; 2012 Eindhoven gold) Listed in Olympians Who Received the Italian Olympic Association (CONI) Gold Medal ()

name: Mario Ustolin
description: Italian Mario Ustolin dabbled in football, basketball, and rugby prior to taking up rowing as an athletic pursuit in 1941. His victories in several national senior events during the 1947 season were enough to earn him a spot on Italy’s national rowing delegation to the 1948 Summer Olympics. He competed alongside Francesco Dapiran in the double sculls event and was eliminated in the semi-finals by the eventual silver medal winning Danish team. In 1950 he won a silver medal in the same event with partner and future Olympian Silvio Bergamini and repeated this feat the following year with Bruno Cressa. He prepared himself to compete at the 1952 Summer Olympics, but was put out of a commission by an operation on a slipped disc. Shortly after he began coaching with his home club, Ginnastica Triestina, and remained there until 1965, when he switched allegiances to the rival club of Vigili del Fuoco. After another spell at Ginnastica Triestina, from 1971 through 1982, he spent three years at Canottieri Nettuno prior to returning to his longtime affiliation and remaining there until his 1991 retirement.

name: Jess Draskau-Petersson
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Were on the Podium at Ironman races (0–0–1 2004 Ironman Austria; Klagenfurt, AUT third)

name: Melanie Booth

name: Vít Fousek, Jr.
special_notes: Son of Vít Fousek, Sr.

name: Martin Hoffmann
description: Forward Martin Hoffmann was a member of the East German (GDR) football team that beat Poland 3-1 at the Montréal Olympics to become the first German team to win an Olympic gold medal. He scored the goal for 2-0 in the 14th minute. From 1973-81 he played 66 international matches with the East German national team, and also nine more with the Olympic team. He was also on the East German team that surprisingly beat West Germany 1-0 in the 1974 World Cup. In his youth Hoffmann played with BSG Aktivist Gommern, but as an adult he only played with 1. FC Magdeburg in 256 Oberliga matches, scoring 78 goals from 1972-85. He helped them to win two national titles (1974, 1975) and three national cups (1978, 1979, 1983). His greatest moment came in 1974, when he won the European Cup Winners’ Cup against AC Milano winning 2-0. He is the only East German soccer player who won both this cup and an Olympic gold, and was also on the 1974 World Championship team. Hoffmann later started a coaching career as a youth coach with 1. FC Magdeburg. From 1994-96 he was named chief coach of the club. He was a graduated sports teacher.

name: Walapa Tangjitsusorn
description: Walapa Tangjitnusorn was the leading female Thai sprinter most of the 1980-ies. Under her maiden name Pinij she was on the gold winning 4×100 m team in the Asian Games in 1978. In the Asian Championships in 1983 she was member of the gold medal teams both in 4×100 m and 4×400 m. Her latest gold medal was in Asian Championships 1985 in the 4×100 m. Her only individual medal was silver in 100 m at the Asian Championship 1983. In 1983 she participated in the first World Athletic Championship in 100 m, before being selected for the Olympic Games in 1984. Personal Best: 100 – 11.72 (1985).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–2–0 1978 Bangkok ATH gold: 4×100 m relay (competed as Walapa Pinji); 1982 New Delhi ATH silver: 4×100 m relay (competed as Walapa Pinji); 1986 Seoul ATH silver: 4×100 m relay)

name: Florrie Barker
description: Florrie Barker won the Northern Counties junior 75 yards freestyle title in 1921 at the age of 13, and three years later was an Olympic silver medallist. She appeared at her first ASA Championships in 1923, finishing fourth in the 220 yards free, and the following year added two third places in the ASA 100 and 220 to the Northern Counties senior title she won that year. A dramatic victory in the 100 metres freestyle in the final Olympic trial at Blackpool, when she beat Connie Jeans on the line by inches, and with the first five virtually in a line, secured her a place on the British team for the Paris Olympics. She was one of three Southport residents, along with Jack Taylor (1500 metres) and Irene Hatch (4x100 free relay first reserve), on the swimming team. Barker returned home with a silver medal as part of the relay quartet. After her Olympic success, she joined the Warrington Swimming Club in 1925 before a return to Southport Victoria shortly afterwards.

name: David Zhuang
description: David Zhuang played table tennis at the 1996, 2000, and 2008 Olympics, playing singles all three years and doubles in 2000. Zhuang was Chinese-born as Zhuang Yongxiang, but moved to the United States in 1990. Internationally he won gold medals at the 1999 Pan American Games in singles and team. He was US Champion 21 times, winning the singles in 1994-95, 1998, 2000, 2006, and 2008; the doubles in 1992-94, 1999-2001, 2003, 2006, and 2008; and the mixed doubles in 1992-95, and 1998-99. He and his wife, Joannie Fu, settled in New Jersey. Zhuang was inducted into the USA Table Tennis Hall of Fame in 2003.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (2–0–0 1999 Winnipeg TTN gold: singles and team)

name: Michael Anthony Nunes
special_notes: Son of Michael Keith Nunes Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (1–0–1 1966 San Juan SAI bronze: Dragon; 1974 Santo Domingo SAI gold: Flying Dutchman)

name: Achim Krause-Wichmann
description: Rower Achim Krause-Wichmann participated in the coxless four with Werner Biel, his brother Hans, and Hanns Peters at the Helsinki Olympics in 1952, the highlight of his career. The boat won its heat in 6:40.8 minutes ahead of the favored Norway and Italy boats. They lost their semi-final and also closely lost the repêchage semi-final and missed the final. Achim came third at the 1954 German Championships in the coxless pairs with non-Olympian Werner Häring, and in 1955 Achim and his brother Hans finished second in the coxed pairs.
special_notes: Brother of Hans Krause-Wichmann

name: Albert Oldman
description: Albert Oldman, a City of London policeman who had earlier served in the Horse Guards, qualified for the final of the heavyweight division at the 1908 Olympics with a quick KO over Ian Myrams of Manchester followed by a bye in the semi-finals. In the final, Oldman faced Syd Evans of Reading, the current ABA champion, but unfortunately Evans had injured his shoulder in an earlier round and was no match for the aggressive policeman. Oldman won by a KO within two minutes and took the gold medal after fighting for a total of less than one round throughout the entire competition. In 1910, he left England to join the Ceylon police.

name: Aldo Stella
special_notes: Brother of Franco Stella

name: Art Rosenkampff
description: Art Rosenkampff represented the New York Turnverein at the 1904 Olympics. He made his living as an accountant and became a professor of accounting at New York University. He published the books, “Bookkeeping – Theory and Practice” and “The Theory of Accounts”.

name: Yun Ji-Su
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–1–2 2017 Leipzig silver: sabre team; 2018 Wuxi bronze: sabre team; 2019 Budapest bronze: sabre team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (2–0–0 2014 Incheon FEN gold: sabre team; 2018 Jakarta/Palembang FEN gold: sabre team)

name: Carl-Åke Ljung
description: Carl-Åke Ljung was a Swedish sprint canoer who competed during the 1950s. Ljung won gold in the K1 4×500 metres at the 1954 Canoe Sprint World Championships in Mâcon with Lars Glassér, Gert Fredriksson, and the non-Olympian Bert Nilsson. Two years later Ljung and Ragnar Heurlin competed in the K-2 1000 metres at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics where they finished in fourth place in their heat and were eliminated.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (1–0–0 1954 Mâcon gold: K1 4×500 m)

name: John Hein
description: John Hein wrestled for the Boy’s Club of New York at the 1904 Olympics. Though Bob Curry threw him in the finals, Hein later won three AAU titles – in 1905, 1910, and 1913. After retiring from competition, Hein became a coach and trainer. During his own competitive days, he had boxed often while training, and he used this to good effect as one of the early trainers of Benny Leonard, world lightweight professional boxing champion.

name: Albert Loibl
description: Ice hockey forward Albert Loibl competed at the 1964 Innsbruck Winter Olympics tournament, with the German team finishing seventh. He earned 20 international caps with the West German national team. Domestically Loibl played for SC Riessersee, EC Bad Tölz, and Augsburger EV, and finished his career with one year with Mittenwald EV. He won the West German title in 1960 with Riessersee, and in 1966 with Bad Tölz.

name: Irmintraut Schneider
description: At the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics German swimmer Irmintraut Schneider came in fourth with the 4x100 freestyle relay. She competed for Borussia-Poseidon in Stettin, now a Polish town. No more results could be identified for Schneider.

name: Pedro Yoma
description: Personal Best: 400H – 53.2 (1952).

name: Willy Angst
description: Willy Angst had the following finishes at major championships – 1937 European Championship: 72.0 kg. Freestyle (2nd); 1935 European Championship: 72.0 kg. Freestyle (3rd).
special_notes: Brother of Max Angst Brother of Heiri Angst

name: Sven Lakenmacher
description: German handball backcourt player Sven, son of Wolfgang Lakenmacher, placed fifth with his team at the Sydney Olympics in 2000. He won 47 international caps and scored 93 goals. At club level, Lakenmacher played with SC Magdeburg (1987-90), TV Großwallstadt (1990-97), TuS Nettelstedt (1997-2003), Portland San Antonio in Spain (2003-04), Eintracht Hildesheim (2004-08), and HF Springe (2008-11). He helped Nettelstedt win the Euro-City-Cup in 1998, and San Antonio the European Cup Winners’ Cup in 2004. Lakenmacher turned to coaching after his active career and worked with HF Springe (2008-11 and 2014-15), HSV Hannover-Burgdorf (2011-14), and Sportfreunde Söhre (from 2016). His daughter Mia also became a handball professional and his son Fynn was a football professional with TSV 1860 München.
special_notes: Son of Wolfgang Lakenmacher

name: Peter Glemser
description: Cyclist Peter Glemser won the 1962 West German Madison championship. He then became a member of the mixed German 100 km time trial team at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics, which finished 14th. Only one year later he turned pro and placed second at the West German road championships. In 1966 he won the “Around Köln (Cologne)” tour and the 1967 Tour de l’Oise. In 1968 Glemser won the individual pursuit on the track and rode the Tour de France. The next year he won two West German pro titles, one on the track in the sprint, and one in the road race, before he retired after the 1970 season.

description: Toshitada Yoshida had the following finishes at major championships – 1969 World Championship: 68.0 kg. Freestyle (5th); 1970 Asian Games: 74.0 kg. Freestyle (1st).

name: Werner Otto
description: Werner Otto was one of the most successful East German track cyclists in the 1960s and 1970s. Together with team-mate Hans-Jürgen Geschke, he reached the tandem quarter-finals at the 1968 Mexico Olympics. At München four years later, they won the silver medal, and in the sprint event, Otto was eliminated in the repêchage. Both Otto and Geschke won two tandem World titles, in 1969 and 1971, and added a silver (1970) and bronze medal (1973) to their collection. They also won the East German tandem title from 1968-71. After his active cycling career, Otto studied sports science at the DHfK Leipzig, and became a successful cycling coach. Later he owned a cycling shop in Berlin, and founded the cycling club RSV Werner Otto Berlin.

name: Fortunato Franco
description: Fortunato Franco was a Goan who was on the Indian football team at the 1960 Olympic Games, but he never played a match in Roma. He did play and help India win gold at the 1962 Asian Games. Franco played mostly for Tata Football Club in Mumbai, where he worked in the company’s public relations department. He captained his state side, the Maharashtra team, for eight years from 1959-66, leading them to the Santosh Trophy title in 1964. In his last years he played for the Goan team Salgaocar. A knee injury ended his career in 1966. In 2021 Franco was a victim of COVID-19.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–0–0 1962 Jakarta FBL gold)

name: Anikó Kapros
special_notes: Daughter of Anikó Kéry

name: Toyoko Yoshino
description: Toyoko Yoshino was a Japanese weight thrower who competed in discus throw at the 1952 and 1956 Olympics. She was also entered in the shot put in 1952, but did not start. Yoshino starred at the 1951 Asian Games when she won titles in the shot put, discus throw and javelin throw, and she repeated in the shot and discus at the 1954 Asian Games, winning five gold medals in all. As a young girl Yoshino started with athletics and was already a multiple Japanese champion before the war - in the 100 metres (2 times), 4 x 100 metre relay (2), long jump (3) and pentathlon (2). In the latter, she set a Japanese record in 1938. After the war, she turned to discus throw and shot put. In discus throw, Yoshino won eight consecutive national titles (1949-56) and in the shot put, she won five (1949-1953). With the discus she also set another two national records. Between 1937 and 1956 she claimed 22 Japanese titles, second only to 24 by Rie Yamauchi, who was successful during and after World War II never competing at the Olympics. Yoshino worked for the Yamanashi prefectural office and, after retiring from active competition, as a high school teacher and the Board of Education of Saitama prefecture. After retirement, she started competing in Masters’ events in the discus throw setting several records in different age classes. For many years, Yoshino was considered to be the same athlete as Ko Nakamura, who competed in the discus throw at Berlin in 1936, but this has recently been shown to be incorrect.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (5–0–0 1951 New Delhi ATH gold: shot put, discus throw, and javelin throw; 1954 Manila ATH gold: shot put and discus throw)

name: Elsa Irigoyen
description: Elsa Irigoyen had the following podium finishes at major championships: 1st in the 1951 Pan American Games foil.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–1 1951 Buenos Aires FEN gold: foil; 1963 São Paulo FEN bronze: foil team)

name: Mariusz Trzciński
special_notes: Twin brother of Henryk Trzciński

name: Czesław Nawrot
description: Czesław Nawrot was a Polish rower who competed in the pair at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics, alongside Alfons Ślusarski. Nawrot competed at the 1964 and 1965 European Championships in the eight. He was a graduate of the University of Agriculture in Wrocław. Nawrot rowed for Zawisza Bydgoszcz and AZS in Wrocław.

name: Danielle Carr-McGrath
description: Danielle Carr-McGrath had the following placements at major international championships - Pairs: 1985 World Championships (11th); 1986 World Championships (14th); 1987 World Championships (12th); 1988 World Championships (15th); 1989 World Championships (10th); 1990 World Championships (16th); 1991 World Championships (16th); 1992 World Championships (14th); 1993 World Championships (11th); 1994 World Championships (10th); 1995 World Championships (11th); 1996 World Championships (12th); 1997 World Championships (16th); 1998 World Championships (15th) (with Stephen Carr [AUS]).
special_notes: Sister of Stephen Carr

name: Billy Kerr
description: Billy Kerr first competed internationally in 1978 when he represented Northern Ireland at the Commonwealth Games in the road race and team pursuit. He again represented Ulster at the 1982 Commonwealth Games, helping them to a fourth-place in the team time trial. Kerr competed three times for Ireland at the World Championships in the team time trial, in 1978-79 and 1982, with a best finish for the team of 19th in 1979. Kerr’s two greatest victories came in 1981 and 1982 when he won the Tour of Ireland both years. He also won the Tour of the North in 1978 and 1979, as well as the Sealink International Stage Race in England.

name: Léon Syrovatski
description: Personal Best: JT – 76.68 (1963).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–0–0 1959 Beirut ATH gold: javelin throw)

name: Hans-Jörg Krüger
description: Center Hans-Jörg Krüger was on the West German basketball team at the 1972 München Olympics. The team lost both the classification match for places 9-12 against Australia by only one point (70-69), and also lost the 11th place match by one point against Spain (84-83). He earned 98 international caps. Domestically, Krüger played with FC Bayern München, helping them to win the 1968 West German Cup.

name: Juan Pablo Sorín

name: Dan Payne
description: Daniel Payne had the following finishes at major championships – 1987 World Championship: 130.0 kg. Freestyle (11th); 1987 Pan-American Games: 130.0 kg. Freestyle (3rd); 1987 Pan-American Games: 130.0 kg. Greco-Roman (3rd).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–2 1987 Indianapolis WRE bronze: freestyle super-heavyweight -130 kg and Greco-Roman super-heavyweight -130 kg)

name: Adolphe Groscol
description: Belgian sprinter Adolphe Groscol won the national title in the 200 metres in 1928, earning him a place at the Olympics. At the Amsterdam Games Groscol ran in the 100 metres, 200 metres, and the 4 × 100 metres relay, but did not advance from the heats in any of those. One year after the Olympics he won his second Belgian title with victory in the 200 metres hurdles. Personal Bests: 100 – unknown; 200 – 22.6 (1928).

name: Alois Gottfried
description: Alois Gottfried was an Austrian foil fencer who competed at the 1924 Olympics. He reached the second round with both the Austrian foil team and in the individual event, but did not start in the sabre events for unknown reasons. He competed for Club Hakoah of Wien (Vienna), a Jewish sports club. Gottfried was a lawyer, but because of his religion he did not feel safe in 1930s Austria, and in September 1938 escaped to Zürich, Switzerland, and then Le Havre, France, where he caught the Ile de France ship to the United States. He petitioned to become a US citizen on 18 November 1938. Gottfried then practiced as a lawyer in Los Angeles, where he died in 1996.

name: Lin Zhiai
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–0 1989 Duisburg ROW silver: lightweight coxless pairs)

name: Kirsti Lay
special_notes: Wife of Mathieu Giroux Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 2015 Toronto CYC gold: 4000 m pursuit team)

name: Luciano Mercante
description: Italian sculptor Luciano Mercante won the silver medal at the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games in the Art Competitions in the category Medals with Medagliere (Medals), although a gold medal was not awarded in this category. He presented four one-sided medals with the motifs wrestling, rowing, running, and high jump. After enrolling at the Royal Academy and the Institute of Fine Arts in Venezio, he moved to the relevant institutions in Siena, where he attended courses in sculpture and architecture and graduated in architecture. He moved to Roma, where he attended the School of Medal Art from 1924 to 1927. After an initial phase, during which he dealt with portrait sculptures typical of the 1930s and 1940s, he discovered the art of producing medals and plaques. His legacy was left to the Musei Civici in Padua by his family.

name: Per-Olof Karlsson
special_notes: Son of Hjalmar Karlsson Brother of Arne Karlsson

name: Henri Saint Cyr
description: Henri Saint Cyr was the first rider to win two individual Olympic gold medals in dressage, those coming in 1952 and 1956. He also helped Sweden win team dressage gold medals at both Olympics. Saint Cyr began his Olympic career in 1936 at Berlin when he was on the Swedish three-day event team. As an eventer, Saint Cyr was Swedish national champion in 1935, 1937, and 1939. Saint Cyr later won a World Championship in individual dressage in 1953 at Wiesbaden. In 1956 he took the oath of the competitors at the Equestrian Olympics which were held in Stockholm.
special_notes: Recited the Athletes' Oath at the Opening Ceremony of the 1956 Equestrian Olympics

name: Juan Carlos Navarro

name: Michael Booker
description: Michael Booker had the following placements at major international championships - Men: 1953 World Championships (9th); 1954 World Championships (6th); 1955 World Championships (6th); 1956 World Championships (5th); 1957 World Championships (10th); 1958 World Championships (8th); 1953 European Championships (4th); 1954 European Championships (4th); 1955 European Championships (2nd); 1956 European Championships (2nd); 1957 European Championships (3rd); 1958 European Championships (4th).

name: Leo Nielsen
description: After placing second four times in the Danish Championships (1927, 1930-32) Leo Nielsen finally won the title in the 1934 road race. His greatest individual success was third place at the 1931 World Amateur Championship. At the 1935 Nordic Championships, Nielsen was winner of the individual road race and also a member of the victorious Danish team.

name: Kenji Watanabe
description: Kenji Watanabe was a breaststroker who swam at the 1984, 1988, and 1992 Olympics, competing in both breaststroke events in 1984 and 1992, and the 100 breast in 1988. He made the final of the 200 breaststroke in 1992, finishing seventh. Watanabe won the Asian Games title in the 200 breaststroke in 1986 and 1990. His grandfather, Hisakichi Toyoda, won a gold medal in the 1932 Olympic 4x200 free relay.
special_notes: Grandson of Hisakichi Toyoda Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (2–2–1 1986 Seoul SWM gold: 200 m breaststroke, bronze: 100 m breaststroke; 1990 Beijing SWM gold: 200 m breaststroke, silver: 100 m breaststroke and 4×100 m medley relay)

name: Raymond Wright
description: Raymond Wright attended Princeton, graduating in 1969. He came from an old Princeton family, as his grandfather, also Raymond Wright, had graduated from the school in 1902. Wright was national high school rowing champion in coxed fours in 1965, while at Lakeside High School in Seattle. After college he returned home and lived in the Seattle area.

name: Tiago Splitter
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 2003 Santo Domingo BAS gold)

name: Maximino García
special_notes: Brother of Hugo García

name: Somnath
description: Somnath was one of the top Indian athletics competitors from Punjab in the 1930s, holding national records in hammer throw from 1938 to 1955 as well as discus throw from 1945 to 1952. He also was a frequent competitor in javelin throw. A member of the 1948 Indian athletics delegation to the London Olympic games, he participated in the hammer throw event, but did not advance past the qualifying rounds. He later won a silver medal in the hammer throw at the 1951 Asian Games in New Delhi. By career, Somnath was an educator, serving as the dean of Hissar Agriculture University and founding sports colleges at Jalandhar and Hissar. He remained involved in athletics affairs and led India at the World Volleyball Championship at Moskva in 1952, and served as the Indian captain at the World Veterans Athletic Championships in 1981, International Veterans Athletics in 1982, as well as Asian Veterans Athletics and World Veterans Athletics, both in 1983. He was also a member of the Guru Nanak Dev University senate, Punjab State Sports Council and, program advisory committee of All India Radio Jalandhar. Personal Best: HT – 46.84 (1946).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–1–0 1951 New Delhi ATH silver: hammer throw)

name: Yelena Sayko
description: Personal Best: 10kmW – 41:56 (1996).

name: Edward Dierkes
description: Edward Dierkes played halfback for St. Rose in the 1904 Olympic soccer tournament. Dierkes worked as a clerk at a dry goods store in the 1900s and early 1910s and then worked for more than a decade as a conductor with the Pullman Company. In the late 1920s, Dierkes opened his own tavern in Kirkwood, Missouri, a suburb of St. Louis.

name: Antonio Ciano
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–0–1 2009 Pescara JUD bronze: half-middleweight -81 kg)

name: Corey Cogdell-Unrein
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 2007 Rio de Janeiro SHO bronze: trap (competed as Corey Cogdell)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (1–0–0 2017 Moskva gold: trap team (competed as Corey Cogdell))

name: Sam Colson
description: A javelin thrower at the University of Kansas, Sam Colson won the 1975 Pan American Games gold medal. He was NCAA champion in 1973, after finishing third in 1972, and was AAU champion in 1974. Colson finished third at the AAU Meet in the javelin in 1971 and 1975. Colson was the #1 ranked American javelin thrower in 1974 and 1976, and was ranked in the US top 10 for seven straight years, 1970-76. He was world ranked three times, in 1973-74 and 1976, with a high ranking of #6 in 1974. Colson later became a strength and conditioning coach at Clemson University. In 1985 he was indicted in a steroid scandal, and pled guilty to providing prescription drugs, including steroids, to student athletes at Clemson. He was fined, placed on probation, and ordered to perform community service. Personal Best: JT – 88.64 (290-10) (1973).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1975 Ciudad de México ATH gold: javelin throw)

name: Hans Scherbart
description: The German field hockey team won the silver medal at the 1936 Berlin Olympics after losing 8-1 to India in the final. Forward Hans Scherbart played in the 6-0 win over Denmark in the group stage, in the 3-0 semi-final win over the Netherlands, and in the final. Between 1928-40 he won 31 international caps. At the club level he played for Berliner SV 92 and won the German Championship in 1940.

name: Percy Knowles
description: Percy Knowles competed in three different sailing classes across four editions of the Olympics – 1960 through 1972 – with a best finish of fifth in the Star class in 1968, alongside his stepbrother Durward Knowles, who competed at a total of eight Olympics in this class and won two medals. Although Percy was less successful, three of his descendants also competed at the Games. His sons Andy and Bruce swam at the 1976 Montreal Olympics, while his grandson Jeremy was a swimmer in 2000, 2004, and 2008. Percy himself was a swimmer, and he competed in masters-level swimming into his 80s, alongside his son Andy. By career Percy was a businessman, and he also served as Commodore of the Nassau Yacht Club.
special_notes: Stepbrother of Durward Knowles Father of Andy Knowles Father of Bruce Knowles Grandfather of Jeremy Knowles

name: Devohn Noronha Teixeira
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 2015 Toronto HOK silver)

name: Nhi Lan Le
description: Nhi Lan Le was born in Vietnam but her mother fled Saigon in 1975 with her children after it fell to the Viet Cong. Her mother, Hang Pham Le, started a restaurant in Atlanta, and eventually put nine children through college on her own. Nhi Lan Le attended the University of North Carolina, where she took up fencing, eventually graduating in 1987 with a business degree. Le won two medals at the 1999 Pan American Games, fencing épée, winning bronze in both the individual and team events. She later became a sales accountant for Sun Data.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–2 1999 Winnipeg FEN bronze: épée and épée team)

name: Peter Thiede
description: Peter Thiede was a German rowing cox who participated in four consecutive Olympic Games. At Barcelona in 1992 he partnered Michael Peter and Thomas Woddow in the coxed pairs, but finished an unfortunate fourth. From 1996-2004 he was the cox in the German eights, winning the silver medal in 1996, and then finishing fourth and eighth respectively at the next two Games. He was awarded Germany’s highest sports award, the Silver Bay Leaf, for the 1996 silver medal performance. At World Championships Thiede won three gold medals (1993, 1995, 2006), five silvers (1987, 1989, 1998, 2002, 2007) and three bronzes (1990, 2001, 2005) with the eights. He was on the German eights from 1993-2008 and on the former GDR eights from 1987-90, except 1988. Thiede won 15 national titles and later turned to coaching. He took over the U23 men’s eights at the Regional Olympic Center in Dortmund. By profession, he became a soldier with the Deutsche Bundeswehr.

name: Jo de Boer
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–1–0 1929 Napoli silver: foil)

name: Yuniel Hernández
description: Personal Best: 110H – 13.26 (2001).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 2003 Santo Domingo ATH gold: 110 m hurdles)

name: Charles Bracht
description: Charles-Victor, Baron Bracht, was a wealthy Belgian businessman who led a large international conglomerate that dealt with tropical products, insurance, and construction. The company had offices in Belgium, Zaire, Indonesia, Latin America, and Western European countries. In early March 1978 he was kidnapped while walking to his car in his private parking lot. A month later, his body was found in a marshy dump in Oelegem, an Antwerp suburb. It was later revealed that he was killed by a gunshot wound to the head.
special_notes: Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Baron)

name: Luis Henrique
description: Luís Henrique was a member of the gold medal winning team at the 1979 Pan American Games.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1979 San Juan FTB gold)

name: Stanisław Swatowski
description: Personal Best: 400 – 46.7 (1964).

name: Hias Noichl
description: Austrian cross-country skier Hias Noichl took part in the 1948 St. Moritz and 1952 Oslo Winter Olympics. On both occasions, he competed in the 18 km cross-country and finished 45th and 28th respectively. Noichl won seven national titles; five with the Tyrol relay in 1948-51 and 1953-54, and an individual one over 16 km in 1950. Noichl became far better known as a mountaineer and mountain guide. He undertook several first ascents in the Alps. He was also chairman of the Association of Austrian Mountain and Ski Guides and the International Association of Mountain Guide Associations. During World War II Noichl fought with the German Wehrmacht and was stationed at Norway. In 1944, he returned wounded to Austria. In 1948 he took over the ski instruction school at St. Johann in Tyrol and led it until 1986.

name: Gaetano Carboni
description: Gaetano Carboni was an Italian swimmer. In 1972 he placed second in the 200 butterfly at the Italian Championships, both indoors and out, which qualified him for the München Olympics, where he was eliminated in the first round. Carboni retired from sports quite young and became a writer. He has written for the La Repubblica newspaper and various literary magazines. In the 1990s, under the pen name Sebastiano Nata, he began writing novels, the first of which, L’impiegato, was published in 1995. In 1999 Carboni / Nata won the City of Vigevano prize for his novel La resistenza del nuotatore. In addition to his writing, Carboni has worked as a banker, serving as general manager for Europe of MasterCard Worldwide, which he joined in 1991, after 11 years with the Italian Banking Association (ABI). Carboni graduated in political sciences from Sapienza University in Roma in 1978, and in 1979 obtained a master’s degree in European Politics and Economics from the “Alcide De Gasperi” Institute of European Studies.

name: Dirk Weise
description: East German flatwater canoeists Dieter Lichtenberg and Dirk Weise finished seventh in C-2 1,000 at the 1972 München Olympics. Dirk Weise was also nominated for the C-1 1,000 event and finished an unfortunate fourth. In 1972 and 1974 both claimed the East German titles in the C-2 1,000, in 1974 also in the 500 metres event. Weise also earned national titles in 1972 (then with non-Olympian Danielski) and in the C-1 1,000 in 1972 and 1973. Weise suffered a stroke in 2015 and became wheelchair dependent. He was employed by the sports department of his hometown Babelsberg.

name: Siri Nordby

name: Hu Dongmei
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–0–0 1994 Hiroshima CSP gold: K4 500 m)

name: Adam Krzysztofiak
description: Adam Krzysztofiak greatest international success came as a junior, when he won a bronze medal at the 1969 European Junior Championships. With the seniors, he never medalled, but competed in two World Championships (1970, 1974) and two Olympics. At home, he won four Polish national titles, and twice the Bronisław Czech and Helena Marusarzówna Memorial. Krzysztofiak, a brick layer by trade, ended his career in 1980. He then became a coach for young ski jumpers, and among others taught Robert Mateja to jump. In the last years of his life, Adam Krzysztofiak suffered greatly from a lung disease.

name: Larisa Korotkevich
description: Personal Best: DT – 71.30 (1992).

name: Jordin Andrade
special_notes: Nephew of Henry Andrade

name: Walter Spence
description: Born in British Guiana (now Guyana) to a Scottish father and Indian mother, Walter Spence learned to swim in the Demerara River, along with his brother, where they survived many piranha bites. He quickly began the top swimmer in his native land but moved to Trinidad and later to Canada, for whom he competed in the 1928 Olympics, and later to the United States. In 1930, Spence enrolled at Rutgers University in New Jersey. He was NCAA champion in the 100 free in 1932-34, the first swimmer to ever win three consecutive collegiate championships in the same event. He also represented Brooklyn Central YMCA and Penn AC in 1926-29 in winning multiple AAU titles. Later in his career he competed for the New York AC, where he was joined by his brother Wally and Leonard, who had also emigrated to the United States. In 1935, with Peter Fick, they won the AAU 4x100 freestyle relay title. After retiring from swimming, Walter Spence worked as an insurance salesman for Security Mutual Life Insurance. He died tragically while trying to board a train at the North White Plains station. Almost missing the train, he ran to catch it, but slipped and fell on the tracks, dying a few hours later from his injuries. Walter Spence and his two brothers were inducted together into the International Swimming Hall of Fame in 1967.
special_notes: Brother of Leonard Spence Listed in Olympians Who Set a World Record in Long Course Swimming (100 m breaststroke – 28 October 1927 - 20 May 1932: 1:14.0 (28 October 1927; New York City, USA)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 1938 Sydney SWI silver: 220 yards breaststroke (competed for British Guiana))

name: Willy Bernath
description: Willy Bernath was a Swiss cross-country skier and car builder. In the early 1930s, Bernath completed an apprenticeship as a car body worker in Hamburg and Zürich. He did not go into the car repair business straight away, opting to become a skier instead. Bernath became the Swiss national champion in 1936. Bernath competed in the 18 kilometres at the 1936 Garmisch-Partenkirchen Olympics, finishing in 31st place. Bernath also competed in the Nordic combined where he finished 22nd. After the Olympics, Bernath spent a few months in the United States. On his return to Switzerland, Bernath took over the car repair business that had been founded by his father. From 1938 onwards, Bernath began to manufacture custom-built cars. From 1938 to 1946, fewer than 30 custom-built cars were made leading to the closure of the workshop. Bernath’s car designs were described as being avant-garde.

name: Reşit Karabacak
description: Reşit Karabacak was a freestyler who wrestled at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics. His biggest international achievements came at the 1985 and 1987 European Championships, when he won bronze medals in 90 kg freestyle. Karabacak competed at three World Championships, in 1977, 1983, and 1987, finishing fourth in 1977 and fifth in 1983. At the Mediterranean Games he was a gold medalist in 1983 (middleweight freestyle) and 1987 (light-heavyweight freestyle). Karabacak became a coach, eventually leading the Turkish national team. He died in 2020 from COVID-19 during the pandemic.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Died After Contracting the Coronavirus (COVID-19) () Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (2–0–0 1983 Casablanca WRE gold: freestyle middleweight -82 kg; 1987 Latakia WRE gold: freestyle light-heavyweight -90 kg)

name: İsmail Oğan
description: İsmail Oğan was a Turkish freestyle wrestler who won silver at the 1960 Rome Olympics and the gold medal four years later at Tokyo in the welterweight class. He also earned three medals at World Championships: silver at the 1957 World Championship and two bronze medals in 1959 and 1963. He died of multiple system organ failure in 2022.

name: Ilona Szikora
description: Personal Best: DT – 48.64 (1954).

Greco-Roman (14th); 1997 World Championship: 63.0 kg. Greco-Roman (16th); 1999 Pan-American Games: 69.0 kg. Greco-Roman (2nd); 1995 Pan-American Games: 62.0 kg. Greco-Roman (3rd).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–1 1995 Mar del Plata WRE bronze: Greco-Roman featherweight -62 kg; 1999 Winnipeg WRE silver: Greco-Roman welterweight -69 kg)

name: Lena Asmus
description: Russian-born rhythmic gymnast Lena Asmus helped the German team finish a surprising fourth place at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. This was the best ever rhythmic gymnastics result in German Olympic history. She won 11 German national titles in total, and later became a coach at the Move Artistic Dome in Köln. She also occasionally commented on rhythmic gymnastics events for the German TV channel Eurosport.

name: Manuel Consiglieri
description: Personal Best: DT – 46.40 (1941).

name: Fernando Zylberberg
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (2–2–0 1999 Winnipeg HOK silver; 2003 Santo Domingo HOK gold; 2007 Rio de Janeiro HOK silver; 2011 Guadalajara HOK gold)

name: Tom Morrissey
description: Representing the Mercury AC, Tom Morrissey won the 1908 Boston Marathon, which placed him on the 1908 Olympic team. Morrisey placed 3rd at the 1906 Boston race and then was 17th in 1907. After the 1908 Olympics he never again finished at Boston. Morrissey turned professional in 1909, after the marathon craze had been incited by Dorando Pietri’s finish at the 1908 London Marathon. In May 1909, Morrissey entered the International Marathon Race, held at the Polo Grounds in New York. He did not finish the race, but his effort was described as follow by The New York Times, “Of the men who did not finish, Tom Morrissey was driven to the greatest extreme, he falling in collapse twice [sic] and each time being hustled back to the track and forced to go on by the insistence of his handlers. Long before his final collapse, the crowd clamored for his removal, but an attendant ran beside him and urged Morrissey to keep at it until he fell in a limp heap directly in front of the grandstand, and unconscious [for 10 minutes] while the other runners turned out to pass him.” Personal Best: Mar – 2-25:44 (1908).

name: Maria Diți-Diaconescu
description: Personal Best: JT – 56.64 (1961).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–1 1959 Torino ATH bronze: javelin throw (competed as Maria Diți); 1961 Sofia ATH silver: javelin throw (competed as Maria Diți)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (0–1–0 1962 Beograd silver: javelin throw (competed as Maria Diaconescu))

name: Ralf Ehrenbrink
description: German three-day event rider Ralf Ehrenbrink won two team medals with the West German team at the 1988 Seoul Olympics (gold) and the re-unified German team at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics (bronze). Individually, he was disqualified in 1988 and placed 11th in 1992. In 1996, his German team disappointingly finished ninth. In 1985, Ehrenbrink added a team bronze medal at the Europeans, and in 1987 the silver medal. In 1994, he also won a team bronze at the Worlds, but he never managed to win a national title. Ehrenbrink later became Chief National Eventing Coach. He was awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, Germany`s highest sports award.

name: Vasily Mosin
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (1–5–1 2010 München silver: double trap and double trap team; 2011 Beograd silver: double trap team; 2013 Lima silver: double trap; 2015 Lonato del Garda gold: double trap, silver: double trap team; 2017 Moskva bronze: double trap team)

name: Louis Allis
description: A native of Milwaukee, Louis Allis’s father, Edward P. Allis, invested in the small D. C. Motor Manufacturing firm in 1901. Louis Allis then took over the company and expanded it greatly, with the company’s name changed to The Louis Allis Company in 1922. The company quickly became an innovator and market leader in the design and manufacture of specialty A.C. Electric Motors. The Louis Allis Company revolutionized many mechanical processes, creating safer and more efficient machines. By the 1940s the company had over 1,000 employees. The company was later taken over by his sons, but it eventually moved to Birmingham, Alabama.

name: Ramon Zenhäusern
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (1–0–0 2015 Granada/Štrbské Pleso ALP gold: slalom) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Alpine Ski Championships (1–0–0 2019 Åre gold: team)

name: Kanstantsin Lukaschyk

name: Édouard Candeveau
description: After the Swiss pair Édouard Candeveau and Alfred Felber won the bronze medal in Antwerp with coxswain Paul Piaget, they did even better in 1924, winning gold in Paris, this time with Émile Lachapelle steering. As a sculler in Amsterdam Candeveau did not advance beyond the quarter-final. Between the two Olympic medals Candeveau and Felber twice took the European crown in 1922 and 1923 in the coxed pairs, representing the Société Nautique de Geneva. Candeveau won two more European championships, in the single sculls in 1931 and in 1929 in the double sculls, also winning one silver and one bronze medal.

name: Lucette Moreau
description: Lucette Moreau had the following podium finishes at major championships: 3rd in the 1975 Pan American Games shot put. In the 1975 Pan American Games discus throw she finished fourth. She also finished fifth in discus throw and sixth in shot put at the 1979 Pan American Games. Personal Bests: SP – 16.96 (1975); DT – 58.58 (1976).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1975 Ciudad de México ATH bronze: shot put) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1978 Edmonton ATH bronze: discus throw)

name: Gaston Étienne
description: Belgian all-round track and field athlete Gaston Étienne specialised in the pole vault and the javelin. At the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics Étienne finished in 22nd place in the javelin and 23rd place in the decathlon. After the Olympics he became a two-time Belgian champion in the pole vault (1929, 1931), and a four-time champion in the javelin (1929–30, 1932, 1934). During the late 1920s and early 1930s Étienne improved the Belgian javelin record multiple times, eventually finishing his career with a best throw of 59.34 metres in 1930. Personal Bests: JT – 59.34 (1930); Dec – 4577 (1928).

name: Renato Macario
description: Renato Macario was on the Italian national rowing team in the early years after World War II. The highlight of his international career took place at the 1947 European Championships held in Lucerne when his coxed fours lost the gold medal by just 6/10ths of a second, beaten by a French crew. The following year, at the London Olympics, Macario rowed with the same coxed four, all the athletes from Società Canottieri Sebino, but they failed to reach the final, being beaten in the semi-finals by the eventual silver medalist, Switzerland.

name: Tracy Wilson
description: Before teaming up with long-time partner Rob McCall, Tracy Wilson made an impression on the figure skating community in 1980 when she and partner Mike Stokes were named the Canadian junior champions in ice dancing. Two years later, however, she had a new partner and the first of seven consecutive Canadian titles in ice dancing. Although they placed only 10th at that year’s World Championships, they slowly began to climb the international rankings with 6th place finishes in 1983 and 1984 and 8th at the 1984 Winter Olympics. The improved to 4th in 1985 before earning, in 1986, the first of three consecutive bronze medals at the World Championships, in addition to one earned at the 1988 Winter Olympics, which made them the first Canadian ice dance team to reach the Olympic podium. That year they were also made members of the Canadian Olympic Hall of Fame and the Order of Canada. Wilson and McCall turned professional after the Olympics, spending two years with Stars on Ice. After McCall died of AIDS in 1991, Wilson retired from skating and began working as a commentator for CBS, NBC and TNT in the United States and CTV and TSN in Canada. She also serves as an ambassador for the Sport for Kids Foundation, a charitable organization that helps raise funds to involve youth in athletic activities. Since 1995, the Tracy Wilson and Rob McCall Trophy has been given to the most outstanding pairs team in any sport.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Figure Skating Championships (0–0–3 1986 Genève bronze: ice dancing; 1987 Cincinnati bronze: ice dancing; 1988 Budapest bronze: ice dancing)

name: Ross Wales
description: 1966 when he took the AAU indoor championship. In 1967 he won a silver medal at the Pan-American Games and was the NCAA champion. Wales retired from competition after the 1968 Olympics, enrolling in law school at the University of Virginia. He was called to action in Vietnam, however, but later returned to complete his law studies at the Charlottesville campus. He became a lawyer in Cincinnati and was later president of the U.S. Swimming Federation.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1967 Winnipeg SWI silver: 100 m butterfly)

name: Aleksey Seliverstov
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Bob & Skeleton Championships (1–0–1 2005 Altenberg gold: Four-man; 2006 St. Moritz bronze: Four-man) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Bob & Skeleton Championships (FIBT/IBSF) (0–1–1 2003 Lake Placid bronze: Four-man; 2005 Calgary silver: Four-man)

name: József Tihanyi
description: Personal Best: HJ – 2.21 (1972).

name: Anass Houssein
special_notes: Brother of Aden-Alexandre Houssein

name: Torsten Bréchôt
description: East German judoka Torsten Bréchôt, born Torsten Oehmigen, won the bronze medal in the half-middleweight class at the 1988 Seoul Olympic Games. In 1985 and 1988, he won national titles and was the silver medalist at the 1985 World Championships. Bréchôt later became a physiotherapist, and also started coaching at Berlin.

name: Yvonne Van Bets
description: Yvonne Van Bets starting competing in gymnastics in 1946. The third of seven siblings, her father encouraged her to study sewing classes in the evening, but Van Bets was more active and found it boring, turning to gymnastics. She joined La Royale Saint-Gilloise Club in Brussels and qualified for the 1948 Olympics by finishing fourth in the Belgian Championships. Van Bets later competed at the 1950 World Championships, and at three Belgian Championships. A severe injury she sustained to her hand in 1953 ended her competitive career, but she continued to coach and help train young gymnasts at her club into her 60s.

name: Werner Unger
description: As the East German national team won the inter-national qualification matches in 1963 against the West German amateur national team by a 3-0 win in Leipzig and a 2-1 loss in Hannover, the German Olympic team at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics was an East German one. The team won the bronze medal, beating Egypt, 3-1. Midfielder Werner Unger started his soccer career with BSG Motor Zwickau, but moved to ASK Vorwärts Berlin in 1956. He played for them until 1968 and won East German national titles in 1958, 1960, 1962, 1965, and 1966. With Berlin he played 270 Oberliga matches and 15 European Cup matches. With the GDR national team he earned seven international caps, and with the Olympic team he had five caps.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Participated in the 1960 Olympic Football Qualification Campaign (2 App. - 0 goals - 180 min. played: FRG 0:2 (h), FRG 1:2 (a)) Listed in Olympians Who Participated in the 1964 Olympic Football Qualification Campaign (6 App. - 0 goals - 540 min. played: FRG 3:0 (h), FRG 1:2 (a), NED 1:0 (a), NED 3:1 (h), URS 1:1 (a), URS 4:1)

name: Roger Ninham
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1962 Perth ROW bronze: coxless pairs)

name: Yekaterina Rabaya
special_notes: Daughter of Yelena Rabaya Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–0 2015 Gwangju SHO silver: trap team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (0–1–1 2015 Lonato del Garda bronze: trap team; 2018 Changwon silver: trap mixed)

name: Xu Xiang
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (0–1–1 1995 Lefkosia silver: double trap team, bronze: double trap)

name: Paddy Brennan
description: At the turn of the century, Paddy Brennan was already established as one of the top amateur lacrosse players with the Shamrock Lacrosse Club of Montreal, Quebec. By 1904 he was being offered opportunities to turn professional, but refused them all. He was therefore able to participate in the trials for what would become Canada’s first truly national amateur lacrosse delegation and was selected not only to travel with them to the 1908 Summer Olympics, but to act as a captain. The squad arrived in London six weeks early, but eventually defeated the British team, their only opponents, 14-10 and secured a gold medal. His amateur status also meant, however, that he had to work as a businessman outside of lacrosse, and he his presence on the team was at times sporadic. Work pressures eventually led him to announce his retirement in May of 1909. In 1912, however, he returned to the Shamrocks when the National Lacrosse Union voted to reinstate the role of the field captain, and the Shamrocks’ president refused to take on the role himself. He even played in one more game with the team in July 1915 and scored a goal. Shortly thereafter he left the sport for over a decade, but by the late 1920s he had renewed his interest and began to work to raise its popularity. He also served as the coach of Montreal’s St. Willbrord lacrosse team before taking up that role with the professional Montreal Maroons in the early 1930s. In addition, he held the position of the Maroons’ manager and accepted the role of honorary coach with the Verdun Athletic Club’s amateur lacrosse squad. He remained active in promoting the sport at all levels until the 1950s, when he began to experience heart troubles, and he died in May of 1961.

name: Tokuo Kitani
description: Tokuo Kitani was one of the speed skaters from Manchuria who dominated speed skating in Japan in the early years. In 1930, he was the very first all-round champion at the All Japan Speed Skating Championships. At the same competition, he also won the 500 m and the 10,000 m. In 1931, Kitani was the highest ranked Japanese representative at the World Championships in Helsinki. In this year, he set 11 national records over the distances between 1,500 m and 10,000 m, as well as in the combination. At the 1932 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, Kitani failed to qualify for the final in all four events probably, handicapped by the unfamiliar mass start. He was called to service in Manchuria in 1944 and detained by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II. Kitani died of pneumonia in a camp near Chita, close to the border to Mongolia. Personal Bests: 500 – 47.0 (1935); 1500 – 2:33.9 (1931); 5000 – 9:12.0 (1931); 10000 – 19:25.2 (1931).

name: Vonette Dixon
description: Personal Best: 100H – 12.64 (2007).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 2002 Manchester ATH silver: 100 m hurdles)

name: Hamzeh Zarini
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–1–0 2010 Guangzhou VVO silver)

name: Kelita Zupancic
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 2015 Toronto JUD gold: middleweight -70 kg)

name: Mike Riddle
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Freestyle Ski Championships (1–1–0 2011 Deer Valley gold: halfpipe; 2017 Sierra Nevada silver: halfpipe)

name: Matt O'Dowd
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-12:20 (2002).

name: Gerd Truntschka
description: Ice hockey forward Gerd Truntschka, brother of Bernd Truntschka, earned 215 international caps and scored 51 goals with the West German and later the German national team. He competed at four consecutive Olympic Winter Games from 1980 to 1992. He also competed at nine World Championships and was chosen for the all-star team in 1987. Gerd Truntschka was seen as one of the best ever technical hockey players in Germany, especially in a forward line with his congenial partner Dieter Hegen. In the German Bundesliga he scored 1,420 scorer points, which is the second highest mark ever (through 2019). Truntschka played 858 matches with the clubs EV Landshut (1975-79), Kölner EC (1979-89), Düsseldorfer EG (1989-92), and EHC Hedos München (1992-94). He helped Köln (1984 and 1986–88), Düsseldorf (1990-92), and München (1994) win eight West German Championships in total. Truntschka was named German Player of the Year five times (1984, 1987-88, 1990-91) and was inducted into the German Ice Hockey Hall of Fame. He later founded a company producing and distributing dietary supplements.
special_notes: Brother of Bernd Truntschka Uncle of Nicolas Krämmer

name: Lindolfo Delgado
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 2015 Toronto BOX silver: lightweight -60 kg) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–1–0 2014 Veracruz BOX silver: lightweight -60 kg)

name: Rod McLain
description: Rod McLain graduated from Union College in 1983, where he wrestled and competed in cross-country skiing. He competed at the 1984 and 1988 Olympics in Canadian doubles, placing fifth in the 1984 1,000 metres. McLain won two medals at the 1987 Pan American Games in Canadian doubles, a silver in 1,000 metres and a bronze in 500 metres. He was the 1977 North American Junior Champion and the 1981 US Champion. During his canoeing career McLain continued to compete in biathlon and cross-country skiing.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–1 1987 Indianapolis CAN silver: C2 1000 m, bronze: C2 500 m)

name: Morten Christensen
description: Morten Christensen was a Danish professional tennis player. Christensen achieved a career-best doubles ranking of 104 in the world in August 1986, and a singles ranking of 250 in the world in April 1988. Christensen played in the first round of the doubles tournament at the 1986 US Open and the 1987 French Open. The following year, he competed in both the singles and doubles at the 1988 Seoul Olympics. Christensen lost his first round singles match to the Serbian Slobodan Živojinović in straight sets. In the doubles he teamed with Michael Tauson with the pair reaching the quarter-finals.

name: Bob McLaren
description: Robert McLaren had the following podium finishes at major championships: 2nd in the 1967 Pan American Games 4×400 metres Relay (with Brian McLaren, Bill Crothers, and Ross MacKenzie), 3rd in the 1967 Pan American Games 400 metres hurdles. Personal Bests: 400 – 48.8y (1966); 400H – 50.7 (1968).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–1 1967 Winnipeg ATH silver: 4×400 m relay, bronze: 400 m hurdles)

name: Roger Johnson
description: Personal Best: 400H – 49.8y (1972).

name: Kari Laitinen
description: Kari Laitinen began his hockey career in 1985 with Jokerit Helsinki and played there until 1987. From 1987-93 Laitinen played with HIFK Helsinki and won his only Finnish Championships medals, two bronzes in 1988 and 1992, with them. He then played one season with Jokipojat Joensuu, before playing two seasons in France with ASG Angers and Chamonix HC. Laitinen finished his playing career in 1996-98 with Pelicans Lahti. Internationally Laitinen played with the Finnish national team only in 1988 Olympics, where he won a silver medal.

name: Peter Wilson
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Played First-Class Cricket (Played 2 First Class matches (Oxford University))

name: Joe Dube
description: Joe Dube won the heavyweight gold medal at the 1967 Pan American Games, and was one of the favorites for gold at the 1968 Olympics, along with Leonid Zhabotinsky of the USSR, and Serge Reding. Zhabotinsky won easily, and Dube only lost the silver medal to Reding because he outweighed the Belgian – they lifted the same amount. Dube later won the World Championship in the super-heavyweight class in 1969 in Warszawa, Poland. During his career Dube competed in 7 World Championships, set six world records, and 12 American records. He was also the first American weightlifter to total 1,300 lbs. (591 kg.) in the older three-lift total. Personal Bests: Total – 591 kg. (1,300 lbs.); Press – 210 kg. (463 lbs.); Snatch – 167 kg. (369 lbs.); Clean & Jerk – 215 kg. (474 lbs.).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1967 Winnipeg WLT gold: heavyweight +90 kg) Listed in Olympians Who Participated in the World's Strongest Man Competition (finished 7th in 1979)

name: Jonas Plass
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (0–0–1 2012 Helsinki bronze: 4×400 m relay)

name: Mariano Antonelli
description: Mariano Antonelli was an Italian shooter who specialized in the small-bore rifle. He competed at the 1960 Roma Olympics, ranking 35th in the English match. His career highlight occurred when he placed sixth at the 1958 Moskva World Championships (588 points). He also took part at the 1959 European Championships in Milano (21st in a field of 70) and was 34th at the 1963 Europeans in Stockholm. Antonelli won the 1959 Italian title in small-bore rifle, three positions.

name: Kakha Tsakadze
special_notes: Son of K'oba Ts'akadze

name: Ken Gray
description: Personal Best: 400H – 49.91 (1984).

name: Alex Stieda
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–0–1 1983 Edmonton CYC bronze: 4000 m individual pursuit) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1982 Brisbane CYC bronze: 4000 m individual pursuit)

name: Im Dae-Won
description: Im Dae-Won had the following finishes at major championships – 2003 World Championship: 55.0 kg. Greco-Roman (2nd); 2004 Asian Championship: 55.0 kg. Greco-Roman (2nd); 2005 Asian Championship: 55.0 kg. Greco-Roman (2nd).

name: Adam Marczyński
description: Polish painter Adam Marczyński received an Honorable Mention at the 1948 London Olympics in the Art Competitions in the category Graphic Arts for his work Set of 8 Ink sketches of athletes. The formats of the sheets varied but averaged about 15 x 20 cm. After World War II he belonged to the most important abstract painting group in Poland. Marczyński studied in Krakow and traveled several times in the 1930s to Paris. He painted mainly landscapes, portraits, and still lifes, in the styles of Cubism and Coloration (Post-Impressionism), and after World War II, also of Surrealism. Later, he also painted geometric figure compositions, interiors, landscapes; and eventually changed to abstract works and the creation of image-objects, relief systems, assemblages, and spatial compositions. From 1945-79 he was a professor at the Academy of Fine Arts in Krakow. Additionally, he created various stage sets. In 1959 he participated in documenta II exhibition.

name: Karina Pérez
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-31:30 (2012).

name: Alexandre Bretholz
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–0–0 1967 Tokyo FEN gold: épée team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–0–1 1970 Ankara bronze: épée team)

name: Paul Tirkkonen
description: Paul Tirkkonen had the following finishes at major championships – 1911 World Championship: 67.0 kg. Greco-Roman (3rd).
special_notes: Brother of Theodor Tirkkonen

name: Kurt Sommerlatt
description: In the 1952 Helsinki Olympic football tournament, West Germany beat Egypt 3-1 in the first round before a surprising 4-2 extra time win over Brazil in the quarter-final. They lost 1-3 to Yugoslavia in the semi-final and missed out on a medal after Sweden beat them 2-0 in the bronze medal match. Midfielder Kurt Sommerlatt played for Karlsruher FC Phoenix (1950-52), Karlsruher SC (1952-57), FC Bayern München (1957-59), and then in Switzerland for FC La Chaux-des-Fonds (1959-62). With Karlsruher SC he won the German Cup in 1955 and 1956, and with Bayern München in 1957 and in 1961 he added a Swiss Cup winners’ medal whilst with La Chaux-des-Fonds. He won seven German amateur international caps. After he finished playing, Sommerlatt became a successful coach in the South of Germany. In 1964 he was the first Bundesliga coach of Karlsruher SC before stints with FK Pirmasens, VfR Frankenthal, Borussia Neunkirchen, FC 08 Homburg and SpVgg 07 Ludwigsburg. Beside his coaching engagements he ran his own sports goods shop in his home town of Blankenburg. He died in 2019 after an operation caused by a fall.

name: Lucie Škrobáková-Martincová
description: Personal Best: 100H – 12.73 (2009).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Indoor Championships (0–1–0 2009 Torino silver: 60 m hurdles (competed as Lucie Škrobáková))
